To make this one even easier, use a bag of coleslaw mix in place of the hand-shredded cabbage and carrots. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/beef-cabbage-stir-fry/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n\nSTIR FRY SAUCE\n2 Tbsp soy sauce \n1 Tbsp toasted sesame oil \n1 Tbsp sriracha* \n1/2 Tbsp brown sugar \n\nSTIR FRY\n1/2 head green cabbage \n2 carrots\n3 green onions \n1/2 Tbsp neutral cooking oil\n1/2 lb. lean ground beef \n2 cloves garlic \n1 Tbsp fresh grated ginger\nPinch of salt and pepper \n\nGARNISHES (OPTIONAL)\n1 Tbsp sesame seeds \n1 Tbsp sriracha \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Prepare the stir fry sauce first. In a small bowl stir together the soy sauce, toasted sesame oil, sriracha, and brown sugar. Set the sauce aside.\n2. Shred the vegetables so they are ready to go when you need them. Cut one small cabbage in half, remove the core, and then finely shred the leaves of one half the cabbage (4-6 cups once shredded, save the other half for another recipe). Peel two carrots, then use a cheese grater to shred them (1 cup shredded). Slice three green onions. Mince two cloves of garlic. Peel a knob of ginger using either a vegetable peeler or by scraping with the side of a spoon, then grate it using a small-holed cheese grater.\n3. Heat a large skillet over medium heat. Once hot add the cooking oil, ground beef, garlic, ginger, and a pinch of salt and pepper. Cook the beef until browned (about five minutes).\n4. Add the cabbage and carrots to the skillet and continue to stir and cook until the cabbage is slightly wilted (or fully wilted, if you prefer). Stir in the prepared sauce and the green onions. Top with a sprinkle of sesame seeds and a drizzle of sriracha, then serve.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-02-27T17:17:44+00:00", "duration": "PT1M", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/o7gP-OVF9IA/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/o7gP-OVF9IA?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o7gP-OVF9IA", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4", "4 (1.5 cups each)"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 Tbsp soy sauce  ($0.18)", "1 Tbsp toasted sesame oil* ($0.33)", "1 Tbsp sriracha**  ( $0.05)", "1/2 Tbsp brown sugar  ( $0.02)", "1/2  head green cabbage  ($1.78)", "2  carrots  ($0.22)", "3  green onions  ($0.17)", "1/2 Tbsp neutral cooking oil  ($0.02)", "1/2 lb. lean ground beef*** ($3.90)", "2 cloves garlic  ($0.16)", "1 Tbsp fresh grated ginger  ( $0.13)", "Pinch of salt and pepper  ($0.05)", "1 Tbsp sesame seeds  ($0.08)", "1 Tbsp sriracha  ($0.05)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare the stir fry sauce first. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47 \n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/the-best-weeknight-pasta-sauce/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 lb. ground beef\n1 Tbsp olive oil\n1 small onion\n2 Tbsp butter \n28 oz. crushed tomatoes\n1/2 tsp Italian seasoning blend\nFreshly cracked pepper\nSalt, to taste \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Add the ground beef and olive oil to a pot and saut\u00e9 over medium until the beef is cooked through (about 5 minutes). If you're using a higher fat content beef (10% or higher), you may want to drain the excess fat once the beef has browned.\n2. While the beef is cooking, finely dice the onion. Add the diced onion and butter to the cooked beef. Continue to saut\u00e9 until the onion is soft and translucent (about 5 minutes).\n3. Next, add the crushed tomatoes, Italian seasoning blend, and some freshly cracked pepper (10-15 cranks of a pepper mill). Stir everything to combine.\n4. Place a lid on the pot and allow it to come up to a simmer. Once simmering, reduce the heat to low and let the sauce simmer for 30 minutes.\n5. After a minimum of 30 minutes simmering, add about 1/2 tsp salt, stir to combine, then taste and add more if needed. The flavor of the sauce will deepen and the complexities will pop once the salt is added. Serve over pasta or your favorite roasted vegetables.\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2020-03-15T20:08:14+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/JLKBmRrRuDk/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/JLKBmRrRuDk?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JLKBmRrRuDk", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6", "6 (about \u00be cups each)"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT40M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeIngredient": ["\u00bd lb. ground beef ($3.16)", "1 Tbsp  olive oil ($0.19)", "1 small onion ($0.39)", "2 Tbsp butter ($0.24)", "28 oz. can crushed tomatoes (1 can, $1.52)", "\u00bd tsp Italian seasoning blend ($0.05)", "black pepper (freshly cracked, $0.05)", "salt (to taste, $0.02)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the ground beef and olive oil to a pot and saut\u00e9 over medium until the beef is cooked through (about 5 minutes). The butter is the game-changer. The only adjustments I make is that I usually double the meat because I like my sauce meatier, and I consider the salt listed is a starting point and I adjust/add more if needed. \r\n\r\nAcidity levels in tomatoes vary. If your tomatoes are more acidic, you may need to adjust by adding a TINY amount of baking soda or sugar (or simmer some minced carrots into the sauce -- they'll break down and will counteract the acid). I add half a shredded carrot with the onion, to take the edge off the acidic tomatoes. Use fresh minced garlic instead of garlic powder and also add chopped green pepper with the garlic, a couple minutes after adding the onion. Use imported Italian crushed tomatoes for the best flavor, and a little tomato paste from the tube, for thickness and a little more depth. Still fast and easy! Love it. Rich and hearty and a good amount of fresh veggies. I like 93/7 ground beef for this recipe too. No need to drain off the fat and it doesn\u2019t get too oily/greasy. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47 \n\nGet recipe FAQs, substitutions, and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/tuna-noodle-casserole/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 yellow onion, diced ($0.32)\n4 Tbsp butter, divided ($0.44)\n8 oz. mushrooms, sliced ($1.69)\n3/4 tsp salt, divided ($0.04)\n1/4 tsp pepper ($0.02)\n2 Tbsp all-purpose flour ($0.02)\n2 cups whole milk ($0.40)\n1 cup vegetable or chicken broth ($0.13)\n4 oz. cream cheese ($0.75)\n1/2 cup frozen peas ($0.25)\n8 oz. wide egg noodles ($0.70)\n2 Tbsp breadcrumbs ($0.08)\n2 Tbsp grated Parmesan ($0.22)\n12 oz. chunk light tuna, drained ($1.79)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Finely dice the onion and add it to a skillet with 1 Tbsp butter. Saut\u00e9 the onion over medium heat until softened.\n2. While the onion is cooking, slice the mushrooms. Add them to the skillet with the onion and \u00bc tsp each of salt and pepper. Continue saut\u00e9ing over medium heat until the mushrooms have softened. Remove the mushrooms and onions from the skillet and set aside.\n3. Add the flour and an additional 2 Tbsp butter to the skillet. Cook and whisk over medium heat as the butter melts. Continue whisking as the butter and flour bubbles and foams for about one minute.\n4. Add the milk, broth, and cream cheese to the skillet. Whisk to combine with the butter and flour mixture. Continue cooking over medium, whisking until the cream cheese has fully melted in and the sauce begins to simmer, at which point it will thicken.\n5. Add the frozen peas and the cooked mushrooms and onions back to the sauce. Stir to combine, then season with more salt and pepper (about \u00bd tsp salt and another pinch of pepper). Set the sauce aside.\n6. Begin to preheat the oven to 350\u00baF. Bring a large pot of water to a boil for the noodles. Once boiling, add the egg noodles and boil for about 7 minutes, or just until tender. Drain the noodles in a colander.\n7. While the noodles are boiling, prepare the breadcrumb topping. Melt 1 Tbsp butter, then stir in the breadcrumbs and Parmesan.\n8. Combine the creamy mushroom sauce, cooked and drained noodles, and drained tuna.\n9. Transfer the casserole mixture to a 3-quart casserole dish, then top with the breadcrumb topping.\n10. Bake the casserole for about 25 minutes or until heated through and golden brown on top. Serve hot and enjoy!\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here. https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIME STAMPS \n0:00 Introduction\n0:07 Saut\u00e9 onionand mushrooms\n0:18 Add butter and flour\n0:23 Add milk, broth, and cream cheese\n0:28 Add peas, cooked mushrooms, onions and seasoning\n0:35 Boil noodles\n0:40 Add noodles and tuna\n0:44 Add to casserole dish and top with breadcrumbs\n0:55 Bake\n0:57 Serve and ENJOY", "uploadDate": "2022-07-03T14:00:09+00:00", "duration": "PT1M8S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/eylEeIC7654/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/eylEeIC7654?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eylEeIC7654", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6", "6 servings (1.3 cups each)"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT55M", "totalTime": "PT65M", "recipeIngredient": ["1  yellow onion (finely diced, (250g, 2 cups) $0.78)", "8 oz. mushrooms (cleaned and sliced, $1.94)", "\u00bd cup frozen peas (70g, $0.20)", "8 oz. wide egg noodles (uncooked, $0.81)", "12 oz. chunk light tuna (drained, $2.54*)", "4 Tbsp butter (divided, $0.46)", "1 tsp salt (divided, $0.04)", "\u00bc tsp black pepper (freshly cracked, $0.04)", "2 Tbsp all-purpose flour (20g, $0.02)", "2 cups whole milk ($0.43)", "1 cup vegetable or chicken broth ($0.13**)", "4 oz. cream cheese ($0.91)", "2 Tbsp breadcrumbs (25g, $0.04***)", "2 Tbsp Parmesan cheese (grated, (20g) $0.31)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Gather and prepare all ingredients.", "name": "Gather", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/tuna-noodle-casserole/#wprm-recipe-62993-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Finely dice the onion and add it to a skillet with 1 Tbsp butter. To substitute dried chickpeas for canned, measure out 125g of dried chickpeas and soak them. I just do the slow way, putting them in a bowl with double the amount of water by volume and refrigerating overnight, but you could also use a pressure cooker or try this 2 hour method in the link below (edited because I don't know if this site has spam filters that won't like me posting a link).\r\n\r\nminimalistbaker.com/quinoa-chickpea-buddha-bowl/\r\n\r\nAfter soaking, drain and rinse the chickpeas, and then add them to a pot, cover them in water, and bring to a boil. I do 50 minutes. And then I followed the recipe from step 1 like normal and they came out great. I used adobo seasoning and a touch of ancho chile powder. Perfect for breakfast, lunch, or brunch!", "datePublished": "2021-03-01T09:14:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Spinach-Pie-overhead.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Spinach-Pie-overhead-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Spinach-Pie-overhead-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Spinach-Pie-overhead-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Spinach Pie", "description": "Puff pastry makes this rich and delicious spinach pie a breeze to prepare. Perfect for breakfast, lunch, or brunch! FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/spinach-pie/ \n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 sheet puff pastry ($2.40)\n1 lb. frozen chopped spinach ($1.99)\n1 yellow onion ($0.32)\n1 clove garlic ($0.08)\n1 Tbsp olive oil ($0.16)\n1 cup cottage cheese ($0.40)\n1/4 cup grated Parmesan ($0.44)\n1/8 tsp nutmeg ($0.02)\n1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)\n1/4 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.02)\n3 large eggs, divided ($0.63)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Make sure to take the puff pastry and spinach out ahead of time to thaw (spinach can be thawed quickly in the microwave, if needed, but do not thaw the puff pastry in the microwave). Preheat the oven to 375\u00baF.\n2. Dice the onion and mince the garlic. Add the onion, garlic, and olive oil to a skillet and saut\u00e9 over medium heat until the onions are soft and translucent. Set the onions and garlic aside to cool slightly.\n3. Add the cottage cheese, Parmesan, nutmeg, salt, pepper, and two of the eggs to a bowl, and stir to combine (save the third egg to brush on top of the pastry before baking).\n4. Squeeze out as much water as possible from the thawed spinach. Add the squeezed spinach and saut\u00e9ed onion and garlic to the bowl with the cheese mixture. Stir to combine again.\n5. Place a sheet of parchment paper on your work surface (or dust lightly with flour) and roll the thawed puff pastry out until it's just slightly larger, about 10x10 inches.\n6. Drape the rolled pastry dough out over a pie plate. Spread the spinach and cheese mixture inside the pastry dough, then take the corners and fold them in toward the center. The pastry will not fully cover the top, but that's okay (see step by step photos below).\n7. Lightly whisk the remaining egg and brush it over the surface of the pastry dough. Bake the spinach pie for about 45 minutes, or until the pasty on top has puffed up significantly and turned golden brown.\n8. Remove the spinach pie from the oven, let sit for about five minutes, then slice into eight pieces and serve.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:07 Saut\u00e9 onion & garlic\n0:12 Combine cheese, seasoning, and egg\n0:23 Thaw and squeeze spinach\n0:25 Combine spinach, onion, and cheese\n0:31 Roll out pastry\n0:38 Fill pastry\n0:46 Brush with egg\n0:47 Bake pie\n0:52 Serve and enjoy", "uploadDate": "2022-02-20T17:32:53+00:00", "duration": "PT1M3S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/RiwWmJ4IVT8/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/RiwWmJ4IVT8?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RiwWmJ4IVT8", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["8", "8 slices"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT45M", "totalTime": "PT60M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 sheet puff pastry ($2.40)", "1 lb. frozen chopped spinach ($1.99)", "1  yellow onion ($0.32)", "1 clove garlic ($0.08)", "1 Tbsp olive oil ($0.16)", "1 cup cottage cheese ($0.40)", "1/4 cup grated Parmesan ($0.44)", "1/8 tsp nutmeg ($0.02)", "1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)", "1/4 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.02)", "3  large eggs, divided ($0.63)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make sure to take the puff pastry and spinach out ahead of time to thaw (spinach can be thawed quickly in the microwave, if needed, but do not thaw the puff pastry in the microwave). I got so excited to wrangle up those cubes of beef that I forgot to roll \u2018em in flour before tossing them into the pan. No big deal, though. Once all the meat was cooked and I was ready to add the veggies, I grabbed my flour and some water, whipped up a quick slurry, and stirred it into the pot. Let it cook for about a minute, and boom \u2013 problem solved.\r\n\r\nThe second little hitch in my giddy-up came after I simmered it for an hour and 15 minutes and then added the potatoes. After another 30 minutes, the stew was smelling like a dream, but the juice was a little too thin for my liking. So, I mixed up 1/4 cup of cornstarch with a cup of water and slowly stirred it in. The result? A stew so rich and hearty, it practically begged to be ladled over a pile of noodles.\r\n\r\nAnd let me tell ya, none of these tweaks messed with the downright incredible flavor of this dish. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/oven-baked-steak-fries/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 lb. russet potatoes\n1 Tbsp cooking oil\n1/2 Tbsp paprika\n1/2 Tbsp steak seasoning\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Preheat the oven to 425\u00baF. Wash the potatoes well. Cut each potato into wedges, approximately 12 wedges per potato. (Quarter the potato lengthwise, then slice each quarter into three wedges.)\n2. Add the potato wedges to a bowl with the cooking oil, paprika, and steak seasoning. Toss the potato wedges until they are well coated.\n3. Spread the seasoned potato wedges out over a parchment lined baking sheet, making sure they're in a single layer. Transfer to the preheated oven and bake for 35 minutes, or until they are well browned and crispy. Flip the steak fries once, after about 20 minutes of baking.\n4. In a small bowl, stir together the cocoa powder, brown sugar, cinnamon, and cayenne.\n2. Heat the milk until hot, but not boiling. (Heat in a small sauce pan over medium-low, whisking often, or microwave for about 1.5 \u2013 2 minutes).\n3. Once the milk is hot, whisk in the cocoa and spices. Drink. Caramelized garlic, basil, and Parmesan add BIG flavor! FULL RECIPE BELOW. \n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/tuscan-white-bean-pasta/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n8 oz. linguine or fettuccine ($0.63)\n1 Tbsp olive oil ($0.13)\n1 Tbsp butter ($0.13)\n3 cloves garlic, minced ($0.24)\n1 pint grape or cherry tomatoes ($1.99)\n10 cranks freshly ground pepper ($0.03)\n1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)\n1/2 tsp dried basil ($0.05)\n1 15oz. can cannellini beans ($0.69)\n4 oz. baby spinach ($0.65)\n3 oz. shredded parmesan ($1.89)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Fill a large pot with water and place over high heat to bring it to a boil. Once boiling, add the pasta and cook according to the package directions (boil for 7-10 minutes). Drain the pasta in a colander.\n2. While you\u2019re waiting for the water to boil, mince the garlic. Heat the olive oil and butter in a large skillet over medium-low heat. Add the garlic and saut\u00e9 for about a minute, or until it has softened and become very fragrant.\n3. Add the tomatoes, salt, pepper and basil. Saut\u00e9 the tomatoes until the skins burst and the tomatoes begin to release their juices. It's important to not have the heat under the skillet too high here or the garlic may burn before the tomatoes break down. You want the garlic to brown and caramelize a bit, but not burn.\n4. Once the tomatoes begin to break down, add the spinach and stir it into the tomatoes until it is about half way wilted. \n5. Rinse and drain the can of cannellini beans. Add the beans to the skillet and stir until they are heated through. The tomato juices will have created a thick sauce-like mixture on the bottom of the skillet at this point. Taste the mixture and add a bit more salt if needed. It should be slightly on the salty side in order to properly flavor the pasta.\n6. Add the cooked and drained pasta to the skillet. Toss until the pasta is coated in the sticky sauce and everything is combined. Top with shredded parmesan, plus add a bit of Parmesan to the top of each bowl.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:08 Boil Pasta\n0:15 Saut\u00e9 Garlic\n0:21 Add Tomatoes and Herbs\n0:31 Wilt Spinach\n0:38 Stir in Beans\n0:42 Add Cooked Pasta\n0:48 Top with Parmesan\n0:50 Serve", "uploadDate": "2021-01-10T15:30:09+00:00", "duration": "PT58S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/2-Xcd2FLUtk/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/2-Xcd2FLUtk?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2-Xcd2FLUtk", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["8 oz. linguine or fettuccine ($0.63)", "1 Tbsp olive oil  ($0.13)", "1 Tbsp butter ($0.13)", "3 cloves garlic, minced ($0.24)", "1 pint grape or cherry tomatoes  ($1.99)", "10  cranks freshly ground pepper  ($0.03)", "1/2 tsp salt  ($0.02)", "1/2 tsp dried basil  ($0.05)", "1 15oz. can cannellini beans ($0.69)", "4 oz. baby spinach ($0.65)", "3 oz. shredded parmesan ($1.89)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Fill a large pot with water and place over high heat to bring it to a boil. Ready in 30 minutes, it pairs with chicken, beef, or pork.", "datePublished": "2016-11-28T18:00:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Parmesan-Portobello-Orzo-spoon-1.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Parmesan-Portobello-Orzo-spoon-1-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Parmesan-Portobello-Orzo-spoon-1-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Parmesan-Portobello-Orzo-spoon-1-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Parmesan Portobello Orzo", "description": "This quick and easy side dish is rich and savory, and goes with just about any meal. I promise it will become one of your new favorites! FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/2014/12/parmesan-portobello-orzo/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp olive oil \n2 cloves garlic \n8 oz baby portobello mushrooms\nPinch of salt and pepper \n2 cups uncooked orzo \n3 cups chicken broth* \n1/3 cup grated Parmesan \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Rinse the mushrooms and cut them into thick slices. Mince the garlic. Heat the garlic and olive oil in a large skillet over medium heat for one to two minutes, or until the garlic is soft and fragrant. Add the mushrooms, a pinch of salt and freshly cracked pepper, and continue to saut\u00e9 until the mushrooms have softened and released all of their moisture (5-7 minutes).\n2. Add the uncooked orzo and chicken broth to the skillet. Give it a quick stir, place a lid on top, and let the mixture come up to a boil. Once it reaches a boil, give it quick stir again to loosen any pasta from the bottom of the skillet. Replace the lid, turn the heat down to low, and let the pasta simmer on low heat for 10 minutes. Stir once half way through to prevent the pasta from sticking.\n3. After ten minutes, test the orzo to make sure it's tender (if not, replace the lid and let simmer a few minutes more). Stir the contents of the skillet to redistribute any leftover broth (it will continue to absorb into the pasta). Once the broth has absorbed, turn off the heat.\n4. Sprinkle the Parmesan over the pasta, stir, and then serve.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2017-10-13T18:50:47+00:00", "duration": "PT58S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Tagx2TGzjy0/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/Tagx2TGzjy0?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tagx2TGzjy0", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6", "6 1 cup each"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.32)", "2 cloves garlic ($0.16)", "8 oz baby portobello mushrooms ($2.19)", "Pinch of salt and pepper ($0.05)", "2 cups uncooked orzo ($1.50)", "3 cups chicken broth* ($0.45)", "1/3 cup grated Parmesan ($0.55)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Rinse the mushrooms and cut them into thick slices. I have always liked mine best with a bit of butter, and a light grind of sea salt, but have lately been adding a generous sprinkle of Tajin, that delicious lime flavored \"fruit spice\" often found in either the produce section of supermarkets, or with Hispanic ingredients on the dry goods shelves. If I want faster results, I dice them into 3/4 - 1\" cubes and oven roast. While several folks suggest using the slow cooker, it makes steamed potatoes. While those are delicious, they aren't the same texture as oven roasted. Left over sweets are a handy lunch and also make delicious hash--lots of recipes online, but my fave uses diced bacon to flavor the veggies. Watch sales this month--most years I buy at least10 lbs at about $0.29--they will keep several months in a cool place, like my garage.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Janet"}, "datePublished": "2022-11-05"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Tasty and easy recipe to follow! Making great food is my passion, my purpose, and my favorite thing to share with others.", "sameAs": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/about/", "https://www.facebook.com/budgetbytes1", "https://x.com/Budget_Bytes"], "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/author/beth/"}, {"@type": "Recipe", "name": "Creamy Coconut Curry Lentils with Spinach", "author": {"@id": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/#/schema/person/de533a4dad507aefcf8ea04e131701f9"}, "description": "These rich, creamy, and earthy Coconut Curry Lentils are an easy and delicious vegan option for dinner or weekly meal prep!", "datePublished": "2019-07-13T19:00:50+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Creamy-Coconut-Curry-Lentils-with-Spinach-dip-naan.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Creamy-Coconut-Curry-Lentils-with-Spinach-dip-naan-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Creamy-Coconut-Curry-Lentils-with-Spinach-dip-naan-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Creamy-Coconut-Curry-Lentils-with-Spinach-dip-naan-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Creamy Coconut Curried Lentils with Spinach", "description": "These rich, creamy, and earthy Coconut Curry Lentils are an easy and delicious vegan option for dinner or weekly meal prep! FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/creamy-coconut-curry-lentils-with-spinach/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n 2 Tbsp olive oil \n2 cloves garlic \n1 tsp grated fresh ginger\n1 small yellow onion \n1 Tbsp curry powder\n1 cup brown lentils (dry)\n2 cups vegetable broth\n1 13oz. can coconut milk \n3 cups fresh baby spinach \nFOR SERVING (OPTIONAL)\n4 cups cooked rice \n1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Mince the garlic, grate the ginger, and dice the onion. Add the olive oil, garlic, and ginger to a deep skillet, Dutch oven, or soup pot. Saut\u00e9 the garlic and ginger over medium heat for 1 minute, or just until the garlic becomes soft and fragrant.\n2. Add the diced onion to the skillet and continue to saut\u00e9 over medium until the onion is soft and translucent. Add the curry powder and continue to saut\u00e9 for about one minute more to toast the spices.\n3. Add the dry lentils and vegetable broth to the skillet. Stir to dissolve any browned bits from the bottom of the skillet. Place a lid on top, turn the heat up to medium-high, and bring the broth to a boil. Once boiling, turn the heat down to low, and let it simmer for 20 minutes, stirring occasionally.\n4. After simmering for 20 minutes the lentils should be tender and most of the broth absorbed. Add the can of coconut milk and stir to combine. Turn the heat back up to medium and allow the skillet to come back up to a simmer. Let it simmer without a lid for an additional 10 minutes, stirring often, to thicken the mixture.\n5. Once thickened, turn the heat off. Add the fresh spinach and stir gently until the spinach has wilted. Taste the mixture and adjust the salt or curry powder to your liking, if needed.\n6. Serve over a bowl of rice, and top with chopped cilantro if desired.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-09-23T19:13:16+00:00", "duration": "PT1M2S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/KjuTLTQsRZE/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/KjuTLTQsRZE?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KjuTLTQsRZE", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4", "4 1.25 cups curry lentils + 1 cup rice"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT40M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.24)", "2 cloves garlic ($0.16)", "1 tsp grated fresh ginger ($0.10)", "1 small yellow onion ($0.21)", "1 Tbsp  curry powder* ($0.30)", "1 cup brown lentils (dry) ($0.67)", "2 cups vegetable broth** ($0.26)", "1 13oz. can coconut milk ($1.99)", "3 cups fresh baby spinach ($1.61)", "4 cups cooked rice ($0.60)", "1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro ($0.15)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mince the garlic, grate the ginger, and dice the onion. Add the olive oil, garlic, and ginger to a deep skillet, Dutch oven, or soup pot. Saut\u00e9 the garlic and ginger over medium heat for 1 minute, or just until the garlic becomes soft and fragrant.", "name": "Mince the garlic, grate the ginger, and dice the onion. Add the olive oil, garlic, and ginger to a deep skillet, Dutch oven, or soup pot. Saut\u00e9 the garlic and ginger over medium heat for 1 minute, or just until the garlic becomes soft and fragrant.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/creamy-coconut-curry-lentils-with-spinach/#wprm-recipe-44661-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the diced onion to the skillet and continue to saut\u00e9 over medium until the onion is soft and translucent. Add the curry powder and continue to saut\u00e9 for about one minute more to toast the spices.", "name": "Add the diced onion to the skillet and continue to saut\u00e9 over medium until the onion is soft and translucent. Add the curry powder and continue to saut\u00e9 for about one minute more to toast the spices.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/creamy-coconut-curry-lentils-with-spinach/#wprm-recipe-44661-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry lentils and vegetable broth to the skillet. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/homemade-rice-krispie-treats/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n6 Tbsp butter (salted) ($0.60)\n6 cups mini marshmallows (10oz. package) ($1.00)\n1/2 tsp vanilla extract ($0.14)\n4 cups rice krispie cereal ($0.56)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Line an 8\u00d78 dish with waxed paper or foil and coat lightly in oil.\n2. Add the butter to a pot and melt over medium heat.\n3. Once the butter is melted, add the marshmallows and continue to stir and cook until the marshmallows are melted and incorporated into the butter.\n4. Once the marshmallows are melted and incorporated, remove the pot from the heat. Stir in the vanilla extract.\n5. Add the rice krispie cereal and stir until everything is coated in the marshmallow mixture.\n6. Press the rice krispie mixture into the prepared dish using a lightly oiled spatula. Avoid over compacting the treats.\n7. Allow the treats to cool at room temperature or in the refrigerator until solid. Slice into 9 pieces and serve.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:07 Melt butter\n0:10 Add marshmallows\n0:22 Remove melted marshmallows from heat\n0:23 Stir in vanilla\n0:26 Add rice It also meal preps well for lunches all week!&nbsp;", "datePublished": "2019-05-05T16:05:46+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/One-Pot-Treiyaki-Chicken-and-Rice-close.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/One-Pot-Treiyaki-Chicken-and-Rice-close-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/One-Pot-Treiyaki-Chicken-and-Rice-close-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/One-Pot-Treiyaki-Chicken-and-Rice-close-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "One Pot Teriyaki Chicken and Rice", "description": "This One Pot Teriyaki Chicken and Rice is an easy and satisfying meal that the whole family will love. It also meal preps well for lunches all week! FULL RECIPE BELOW. \ud83d\udc47\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/one-pot-teriyaki-chicken-and-rice/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 boneless, skinless chicken breast (about 2/3 lb.) ($2.81)\n1 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.04)\n2 cloves garlic, minced ($0.16)\n1 tsp grated fresh ginger ($0.10)\n1.5 cups uncooked jasmine rice ($0.99)\n2.5 cups water ($0.00)\n12 oz. frozen stir fry vegetables ($1.59)\n1/4 cup soy sauce ($0.24)\n2 Tbsp brown sugar ($0.08)\n1 tsp toasted sesame oil ($0.10)\n2 green onions, sliced ($0.15)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Prepare the teriyaki sauce. In a small bowl, stir together the soy sauce, brown sugar, and toasted sesame oil. The brown sugar may not fully dissolve, but that's okay. Set the sauce aside.\n2.Cut the chicken breast into very small pieces, about 1/2 to 3/4-inch in size.\n3. Add the cooking oil, garlic, and ginger to a large, deep skillet. Cook over medium heat for about 1 minute, then add the chicken pieces and continue to saut\u00e9 just until the outside of the chicken is no longer pink. Do not over cook the chicken here, it will finish cooking with the rice.\n4. Add the uncooked rice to the skillet and continue to saut\u00e9 for 1-2 minutes more. You should hear the rice popping. Finally, add the water and give everything a brief stir to make sure there is no rice stuck to the bottom of the skillet.\n5. Place a lid on the skillet, turn the heat up to medium-high, and allow the water to come to a full boil. Once boiling, turn the heat down to low and let it simmer for 10 minutes.\n6. After the rice has simmered for 10 minutes, lift the lid briefly to sprinkle the frozen vegetables on top, then replace the lid immediately. Make sure the vegetables are spread evenly over the surface. Let the skillet continue to heat over low for an additional five minute.\n7. After steaming the rice and vegetables together for 5 minutes, turn the heat off and let the skillet rest with the lid in place for an additional five minutes.\n8. Give the teriyaki sauce another brief stir, lift the lid on the skillet, and drizzle the sauce over the vegetables. Make sure to scrape out all the sugar from the bottom of the bowl. Using a spatula or large spoon, gently fold the rice and vegetables together until everything is mostly coated in the sauce. Make sure to scoop all the way to the bottom of the skillet when folding, as the sauce will sink to the bottom.\n9. Place the lid back on top and let the skillet rest for a final 5 minutes to let the flavor soak in (heat turned off). Sprinkle sliced green onions over top just before serving. \n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 One Pot Teriyaki Chicken and Rice\n0:09 Mix soy sauce,  brown sugar and sesame oil in a bowl.\n0:15 Dice chicken breast\n0:22 Add to pan with garlic and ginger\n0:26 Saut\u00e9\n0:29 Add jasmine rice to pan\n0:33 Add water to pan\n0:38 Simmer\n0:42 Add frozen vegetables\n0:46 Steam\n0:50 Fold in sauce\n0:59 Top with green onions", "uploadDate": "2020-09-06T18:24:00+00:00", "duration": "PT1M8S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/MEVB8ja-kXQ/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/MEVB8ja-kXQ?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MEVB8ja-kXQ", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4", "4 about 2 cups each"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT30M", "totalTime": "PT35M", "recipeIngredient": ["1  boneless, skinless chicken breast (about 2/3 lb.) ($2.81)", "1 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.04)", "2 cloves garlic, minced ($0.16)", "1 tsp grated fresh ginger ($0.10)", "1.5 cups uncooked jasmine rice ($0.99)", "2.5 cups water ($0.00)", "12 oz. frozen stir fry vegetables ($1.59)", "1/4 cup soy sauce ($0.24)", "2 Tbsp brown sugar ($0.08)", "1 tsp toasted sesame oil ($0.10)", "2  green onions, sliced ($0.15)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut the chicken breast into very small pieces, about 1/2 to 3/4-inch in size.", "name": "Cut the chicken breast into very small pieces, about 1/2 to 3/4-inch in size.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/one-pot-teriyaki-chicken-and-rice/#wprm-recipe-43843-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the cooking oil, garlic, and ginger to a large, deep skillet. Cook over medium heat for about 1 minute, then add the chicken pieces and continue to saut\u00e9 just until the outside of the chicken is no longer pink. Do not over cook the chicken here, it will finish cooking with the rice.", "name": "Add the cooking oil, garlic, and ginger to a large, deep skillet. Cook over medium heat for about 1 minute, then add the chicken pieces and continue to saut\u00e9 just until the outside of the chicken is no longer pink. Do not over cook the chicken here, it will finish cooking with the rice.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/one-pot-teriyaki-chicken-and-rice/#wprm-recipe-43843-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the uncooked rice to the skillet and continue to saut\u00e9 for 1-2 minutes more. You should hear the rice popping. Finally, add the water and give everything a brief stir to make sure there is no rice stuck to the bottom of the skillet.", "name": "Add the uncooked rice to the skillet and continue to saut\u00e9 for 1-2 minutes more. You should hear the rice popping. Finally, add the water and give everything a brief stir to make sure there is no rice stuck to the bottom of the skillet.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/one-pot-teriyaki-chicken-and-rice/#wprm-recipe-43843-step-0-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place a lid on the skillet, turn the heat up to medium-high, and allow the water to come to a full boil. Once boiling, turn the heat down to low and let it simmer for 10 minutes.", "name": "Place a lid on the skillet, turn the heat up to medium-high, and allow the water to come to a full boil. Once boiling, turn the heat down to low and let it simmer for 10 minutes.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/one-pot-teriyaki-chicken-and-rice/#wprm-recipe-43843-step-0-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While the skillet is simmering over low, prepare the teriyaki sauce. She went on in many directions, but the bottom line was our 4 year old wanted Tony Chachere sprinkled on quesadillas, nachos, cheese and crackers, and french fries. These meatballs are both easy and delicious. Watch this video to learn how to make turkey and stuffing meatballs for your next party, or serve them as part of a Thanksgiving-inspired dinner.\n\nTurkey and stuffing meatballs are the perfect Thanksgiving appetizer. Watch this video to learn how to make these tasty meatballs!  FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs, serving suggestions, and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/turkey-and-stuffing-meatballs/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 6oz. box stuffing mix ($0.69)\n1 cup hot water* ($0.00)\n19 oz. ground turkey (93% lean) ($3.49)\n1 large egg, lightly beaten ($0.26)\n2 Tbsp butter ($0.26)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Place the dry stuffing mix in a large bowl, add the hot water, and stir until no more water pools on the bottom of the bowl. Let the stuffing sit for another 5 minutes to further soften. (Less water is added to the stuffing mix than is listed on the box in order to leave room for the absorption of moisture from the turkey and egg.)\n2. Add the ground turkey and beaten egg to the bowl with the partially hydrated stuffing mix. Combine these ingredients by hand until they are evenly mixed. Form the mixture into 20 meatballs, slightly larger than ping pong balls, or about 3 Tbsp each.\n3. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper, then place the meatballs on the parchment. Bake the meatballs for 20 minutes in the preheated oven.\n4. Melt 1 Tbsp butter in a large skillet over medium heat. Add half of the baked meatballs and allow them to cook in the butter until browned on most sides (about 5 minutes). Transfer the browned meatballs to a serving dish, add a second tablespoon of butter to the skillet, and repeat with the second batch of meatballs. \n5. Serve warm over a bed of mashed potatoes or with gravy or cranberry sauce for dipping.\n\nNOTES\n*If your stuffing mix calls for chicken broth instead of water in the cooking instructions, use chicken broth for the meatballs as well.\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:08 Hydrate stuffing mix\n0:13 Add egg and ground turkey\n0:17 Shape meatballs\n0:25 Bake turkey meatballs\n0:31 Brown meatballs in butter\n0:36 Serve and enjoy!", "uploadDate": "2021-11-14T16:49:38+00:00", "duration": "PT49S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/wvPo9fZJkaM/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/wvPo9fZJkaM?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wvPo9fZJkaM", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["20", "20 meatballs"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT30M", "totalTime": "PT40M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 6oz. box stuffing mix ($0.69)", "1 cup hot water* ($0.00)", "19 oz. ground turkey (93% lean) ($3.49)", "1 large egg, lightly beaten ($0.26)", "2 Tbsp butter ($0.26)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. I don't go looking for vegetarian dishes, but since I and my family love most vegetables and I'm totally mad for mushrooms, this recipe was a definite winner. Even if it isn't fast. \r\n\r\nIn reference to the poster who referred to time as a major budget consideration, on a work day that's definitely true. My family loves soup and stews--lots of inactive cooking going on with those, and they usually result in a fridge or freezer full of great time savers later. FULL RECIPE BELOW. \ud83d\udc47\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/maple-sage-breakfast-sausage/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n19 oz. ground turkey ($3.49)\n1 tsp dried sage ($0.10)\n1/2 tsp dried thyme ($0.05)\n1/4 tsp garlic powder ($0.03)\n1/2 tsp smoked paprika ($0.05)\n1 Tbsp maple syrup ($0.30)\n1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)\nfreshly cracked pepper ($0.03)\n1 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.04)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Add the ground turkey, sage, thyme, garlic powder, smoked paprika, maple syrup, salt, and some freshly cracked pepper to a bowl. Use your hands to mix the ingredients together until the ground turkey is evenly seasoned.\n2. Using a 1/4 cup measuring cup, portion and shape the ground meat mixture into patties. After measuring out 1/4 cup, make sure to flatten the patties until they are very thin, as they'll shrink inward and get thicker in the center as they cook. The shaped patties should be about 3-inches wide.\n3. To cook the Maple Sage Breakfast Sausage, add 1 Tbsp cooking oil to a skillet and heat over medium. Once hot, add the sausage patties (working in two batches if needed to prevent over crowding the skillet) and cook 3-5 minutes on each side, or until browned on the outside and cooked through. Serve hot.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/ \n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Intro\n0:09 Season Meat\n0:25 Shape Sausage Patties\n0:31 Cook Sausage", "uploadDate": "2020-09-20T15:45:02+00:00", "duration": "PT52S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/N8-TN9NS3OI/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/N8-TN9NS3OI?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N8-TN9NS3OI", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["5", "5 two patties each"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["19 oz. ground turkey ($3.49)", "1 tsp dried sage ($0.10)", "1/2 tsp dried thyme ($0.05)", "1/4 tsp garlic powder ($0.03)", "1/2 tsp smoked paprika ($0.05)", "1 Tbsp maple syrup ($0.30)", "1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)", "freshly cracked pepper ($0.03)", "1 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.04)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the ground turkey, sage, thyme, garlic powder, smoked paprika, maple syrup, salt, and some freshly cracked pepper to a bowl. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPrintable recipe: https://www.budgetbytes.com/roasted-cauliflower-and-quinoa-salad/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n 1 head cauliflower \n1 small red onion \n2 Tbsp olive oil \npinch salt and pepper \n2 Tbsp butter\n2 cloves garlic, minced \n1 tsp turmeric \n1/2 tsp cumin \n1/8 tsp cinnamon \n2 cups quinoa\n1/3 cup dried cranberries \n3 cups vegetable broth\n1/4 cup sliced almonds \n1 cup chopped parsley \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Chop the cauliflower into florets and slice the red onion into 1/4-inch strips. Place the cauliflower florets and sliced red onion into a large bowl, along with the olive oil and a pinch of salt and pepper. Toss the cauliflower and onion until they are well coated in oil.\n2. Spread the cauliflower and onion out onto a large baking sheet, then transfer them to the oven. Roast the vegetables for 20 minutes, give them a good stir, then roast for an additional 10-15 minutes, or until the onions are caramelized and the cauliflower is browned.\n3. Meanwhile, prepare the quinoa. Rinse the quinoa well in a wire mesh sieve. Add the butter, garlic, turmeric, cumin, and cinnamon, to a medium sauce pot. Place the pot over medium heat. Stir and cook the spices for one minute.\n4. Add the drained quinoa to the pot with the butter and spices. Also add the dried cranberries and vegetable broth. Stir to combine, then place a lid on the pot, turn the heat up to medium-high, and bring it up to a boil. Once it reaches a boil, turn the heat down to low and let the pot simmer for 20 minutes, with the lid in place.\n5. After simmering over low for 20 minutes, the quinoa should have absorbed all of the broth. Remove the lid and fluff the quinoa. Add the sliced almonds and stir to combine. \n6. Allow the quinoa to cool slightly.\n7. Transfer the cooked quinoa and roasted cauliflower and red onion to a large bowl. Add the chopped parsley and stir until everything is combined. Serve immediately, or refrigerate until ready to eat (can be eaten warm or cold). \n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-09-28T19:31:21+00:00", "duration": "PT1M3S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/CFQMG7Ny3v0/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/CFQMG7Ny3v0?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CFQMG7Ny3v0", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6", "6 2 cups each"], "prepTime": "PT20M", "cookTime": "PT35M", "totalTime": "PT55M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 head cauliflower  ($3.49)", "1 small red onion ($0.28)", "2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.32)", "pinch  salt and pepper ($0.05)", "2 Tbsp butter ($0.12)", "2 cloves garlic, minced ($0.08)", "1 tsp turmeric ($0.10)", "1/2 tsp cumin ($0.05)", "1/8 tsp cinnamon ($0.02)", "2 cups quinoa ($2.39)", "1/3 cup dried cranberries ($0.29)", "3 cups vegetable broth* ($0.39)", "1/4 cup sliced almonds ($0.44)", "1 cup chopped parsley ($0.45)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. I am a sucker for the turmeric/butter combo and I love yellow rice, but I had this saved for so long since I was nervous to try quinoa. If all quinoa is this good it might be my new favorite grain! As another commenter mentioned, check the liquid ratio on your quinoa packet and use that amount of vegetable broth. Mine was 2 cups liquid to 1 cup dry quinoa. The jammy red onions, crunchy almonds, sweet cranberries, and smokey cauliflower work SO well with this yellow quinoa. I halved everything except the cauliflower as this is quite a large recipe. My only other change was using cilantro instead of parsley. We ate it with sauteed kale and roasted cubed potatoes. It doesn't need a sauce, but Trader Joes Jalapeno sauce and/or Green Goddess dressing (depending on your spice preference) went marvelously for us.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Vee Glessner"}, "datePublished": "2020-07-20"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "reviewBody": "This recipe has great flavor. "https://slickstream.com", "@graph": [{"@type": "Plugin", "version": "3.0.1"}, {"@type": "Site", "name": "Budget Bytes", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com", "description": "Delicious Recipes Taste the gravy and add a pinch of salt or pepper if needed. Mine had plenty of salt, so I only needed to add a pinch of freshly cracked black pepper. Remove the pan from the heat and serve. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs, substitutions, and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/sausage-breakfast-casserole/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 lb. country sausage ($3.49)\n12 oz. frozen peppers and onions ($1.25)\n10 large eggs ($2.08)\n1/2 cup milk ($0.20)\n1/4 tsp pepper ($0.02)\n1/2 lb. tortilla chips* ($1.50)\n8 oz. cheddar, shredded ($2.29)\n1 Tbsp butter ($0.10)\n\n1. INSTRUCTIONS\nPreheat the oven to 350\u00baF. If your frozen peppers are in strips, chop them into small pieces.\n2. Brown the sausage in a large skillet over medium heat. Once browned, add the frozen peppers and onions and continue to cook over medium heat until heated through. Remove the sausage and peppers from the heat and set aside.\n3. Whisk together the eggs, milk, and pepper.\n4. Use the butter to grease the inside of a 3-quart casserole dish. Place the tortilla chips in the bottom of the casserole dish and press them down, slightly crushing them until they lay fairly flat.\n5. Use a slotted spoon to transfer the sausage and peppers to the casserole dish on top of the tortilla chips, leaving any liquid behind in the pan.\n6. Add \u00be of the shredded cheddar on top of the sausage and peppers. Stir slightly to combine the tortilla chips, sausage and peppers, and cheese.\n7. Pour the egg mixture over the ingredients in the casserole dish, then top with the remaining shredded cheddar. The ingredients will not be fully submerged in the egg mixture and that is okay. The eggs will puff slightly as they bake.\n8. Bake the breakfast casserole for about 40 minutes, or until the internal temperature reaches 160\u00baF and the outer edges are lightly browned.\n9. Let the casserole cool for about five minutes, then slice into six or eight pieces and serve.\nNOTES\n* You don\u2019t have to weigh the chips. Check the weight listed on the bag and approximate the amount based on the bag size. For instance, if you have a one-pound (16oz.) bag, use about half of the bag of chips.\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here. https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:07 Brown Sausage\n0:10 Add onions and peppers\n0:16 Whisk eggs, milk, and pepper\n0:22 Butter casserole dish \n0:24 Layer ingredients\n0:40 Bake\n0:43 Serve and ENJOY", "uploadDate": "2022-05-22T14:00:12+00:00", "duration": "PT57S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/uhFOjxCsZVs/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/uhFOjxCsZVs?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uhFOjxCsZVs", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6", "6 to 8"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT50M", "totalTime": "PT60M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 lb. country sausage ($3.49)", "12 oz. frozen peppers and onions ($1.25)", "10 large eggs ($2.08)", "1/2 cup milk ($0.20)", "1/4 tsp pepper ($0.02)", "1/2 lb. tortilla chips* ($1.50)", "8 oz. cheddar, shredded ($2.29)", "1 Tbsp butter ($0.10)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00baF. That added some additional depth of flavor and made the dish considerably more savory, so it was more satisfying. It needs a super crisp thin crust and a meltingly soft and tender inside. Panera Bread's baguettes, although delicious, are too dense for these sandwiches. I'm lucky to have an independent baker in my smallish NC community who does perfect baguettes, so it's worth looking around your town to maybe find the real deal. This recipe produces incredible fried shrimp and catfish (I tried both, and didn't miss the cornmeal with the catfish strips). If you can't find the right bread just pile fried seafood and veggies on toast or serve the fried shrimp over a bed of lettuce, chopped tomatoes, and cucumbers and use the remoulade as a dressing. It makes a great side dish or bed for chicken or fish.\u00a0", "datePublished": "2021-03-16T15:30:24+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/Lemon-Parsley-Pasta-side.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/Lemon-Parsley-Pasta-side-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/Lemon-Parsley-Pasta-side-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/Lemon-Parsley-Pasta-side-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Lemon Parsley Pasta", "description": "Lemon Parsley Pasta is bright, garlicky, and full of rich Parmesan flavor. It makes a great side dish or bed for chicken or fish. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/lemon-parsley-pasta/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n8 oz. thin spaghetti ($0.50)\n1 fresh lemon ($0.89)\n2 cloves garlic, minced ($0.16)\n1/2 cup chopped fresh parsley ($0.70)\n1/8 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.02)\n1 Tbsp olive oil ($0.16)\n2 Tbsp butter ($0.14)\n2 Tbsp grated Parmesan ($0.22)\n1/4 tsp salt ($0.02)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Bring a large pot of water to a boil for the pasta. Once boiling, add the pasta and boil until tender (about 7-8 minutes). Drain the pasta in a colander.\n2. While the pasta is cooking, zest the lemon (you'll need about 1 Tbsp). Chop the parsley and combine it with the Parmesan, lemon zest, and pepper in a bowl. Set the bowl aside.\n3. While the pasta is draining, add the olive oil and minced garlic to the pot used to cook the pasta. Saut\u00e9 the garlic in the oil over medium heat for 1-2 minutes, or just until it becomes fragrant.\n4. Remove the pot from the heat and add the drained pasta and butter to the pot with the garlic. Toss the pasta until the residual heat has melted the butter and the pasta is coated in garlic and butter.\n5. Add the parsley Parmesan mixture to the pot and toss to coat again. Squeeze about 1 Tbsp of the lemon juice over the pasta and season with salt (about \u00bc tsp). Toss to combine, then taste, and adjust the salt, pepper, or Parmesan to your liking. Serve warm.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:09 Zest lemon\n0:11 Chop parsley\n0:14 Combine parsley, lemon, Parmesan, and pepper\n0:22 Cook pasta\n0:31 Saut\u00e9 garlic\n0:34 Add pasta and butter\n0:40 Add parsley mixture\n0:42 Toss to combine and season with salt\n0:46 Serve and enjoy", "uploadDate": "2021-04-18T16:00:16+00:00", "duration": "PT55S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Qr7kcCUkAM8/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/Qr7kcCUkAM8?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qr7kcCUkAM8", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["8 oz. thin spaghetti ($0.50)", "1  fresh lemon ($0.89)", "2 cloves garlic, minced ($0.16)", "1/2 cup chopped fresh parsley ($0.70)", "1/8 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.02)", "1 Tbsp olive oil ($0.16)", "2 Tbsp butter ($0.14)", "2 Tbsp grated Parmesan ($0.22)", "1/4 tsp salt ($0.02)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bring a large pot of water to a boil for the pasta. And the second layer could actually be fully prepared while the first layer was in the oven :) which is rare in my experience.\r\n\r\nThis recipe turned out really well. A few things I changed slightly: I used full-fat oat milk rather than dairy milk, and I didn't have lemon juice so substituted with about 2/3 tbsp water and 1/3 tbsp apple cider vinegar. Everything cooks in one pot and is done in under 30 minutes!\u00a0", "datePublished": "2025-01-09T08:30:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Creamy-Pesto-Chicken-Pasta-close-plate.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Creamy-Pesto-Chicken-Pasta-close-plate-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Creamy-Pesto-Chicken-Pasta-close-plate-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Creamy-Pesto-Chicken-Pasta-close-plate-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "One Pot Creamy Pesto Chicken Pasta", "description": "This super lush and Creamy Pesto Chicken Pasta is perfect for busy weeknights. Everything cooks in one pot and is done in under 30 minutes! FULL RECIPE BELOW. \ud83d\udc47\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/one-pot-creamy-pesto-chicken-pasta/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 lb. boneless, skinless chicken breast ($5.56)\n2 Tbsp butter ($0.26)\n2 cloves garlic ($0.16)\n1/2 lb. penne pasta ($0.40)\n1.5 cups chicken broth ($0.20)\n1 cup milk ($0.32)\n3 oz. cream cheese ($0.29)\n1/3 cup basil pesto ($0.73)\n1/4 cup grated Parmesan ($0.44)\nfreshly cracked pepper ($0.03)\n1 pinch crushed red pepper ($0.02)\nOPTIONAL ADD-INS\n3 cup fresh spinach ($0.90)\n1/4 cup sliced sun dried tomatoes ($1.10)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Cut the chicken breast into 1-inch pieces. Add the butter to a deep skillet and melt over medium heat. Add the chicken to the skillet and cook over medium heat until the chicken is slightly browned on the outside.\n2. While the chicken is cooking, mince the garlic. Add the garlic to the skillet with the chicken and continue to saut\u00e9 for one minute more.\n3. Add the uncooked pasta and chicken broth to the skillet with the chicken and garlic. Stir to dissolve any browned bits from the bottom of the skillet. Place a lid on the skillet, turn the heat up to medium-high, and bring the broth up to a boil.\n4. Once the broth comes to a full boil, give the pasta a quick stir, replace the lid, and turn the heat down to medium-low. Let the pasta simmer over medium-low heat for about 8 minutes, or until the pasta is tender and most of the broth has been absorbed. Stir the pasta briefly every two minutes as it simmers, replacing the lid quickly each time.\n5. Once the pasta is tender and most of the broth absorbed, add the milk, cream cheese (cut into chunks), and pesto. Stir and cook over medium heat until the cream cheese has fully melted into the sauce. Finally, add the grated Parmesan and stir until combined.\n6. If using, add the fresh spinach and sliced sun dried tomatoes. Stir until the spinach has wilted, then remove the pasta from the heat. Top the pasta with freshly cracked pepper and a pinch of crushed red pepper, then serve.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:09 Saut\u00e9 Chicken in Butter\n0:14 Add Minced Garlic\n0:17 Add Pasta and Broth\n0:24 Simmer\n0:31 Stir in Cream Cheese, Pesto, and Milk\n0:43 Add Parmesan\n0:47 Season with Pepper and Crushed Red Pepper\n0:49 Fold in Sun Dried Tomatoes and Spinach\n1:00 Serve and Enjoy!", "uploadDate": "2020-12-06T16:30:02+00:00", "duration": "PT1M8S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/cxTSOlWNXy0/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/cxTSOlWNXy0?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cxTSOlWNXy0", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT25M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 lb. boneless, skinless chicken breast ($6.25)", "2 Tbsp butter ($0.28)", "2 cloves garlic ($0.16)", "1/2 lb. penne pasta ($0.67)", "1.5 cups chicken broth ($0.20)", "1 cup milk ($0.19)", "3 oz. cream cheese* ($0.80)", "1/3 cup basil pesto ($0.73)", "1/4 cup grated Parmesan ($0.44)", "freshly cracked pepper ($0.03)", "1 pinch  crushed red pepper ($0.02)", "3 cup fresh spinach ($0.90)", "1/4 cup sliced sun dried tomatoes ($1.10)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut the chicken breast into 1-inch pieces. Slice the head in half and remove the core (see photos below). Cut each half into two then cut crosswise as thinly as possible. You need a very small shred to make the pot stickers easy to fill and fold.", "name": "Peel off the outer leaves from the cabbage. Slice the head in half and remove the core (see photos below). Cut each half into two then cut crosswise as thinly as possible. You need a very small shred to make the pot stickers easy to fill and fold.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/pork-ginger-pot-stickers/#wprm-recipe-33891-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large skillet, heat 2 Tbsp of oil over medium/high heat. When it\u2019s hot, add the cabbage and 1/2 tsp of salt. Saute the cabbage until it is translucent and soft (about 15 minutes). Remove from the heat and let cool slightly.", "name": "In a large skillet, heat 2 Tbsp of oil over medium/high heat. When it\u2019s hot, add the cabbage and 1/2 tsp of salt. Saute the cabbage until it is translucent and soft (about 15 minutes). Remove from the heat and let cool slightly.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/pork-ginger-pot-stickers/#wprm-recipe-33891-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While the cabbage is sauteing (stir every minute or so), combine the raw ground pork, peeled and grated ginger (use a small cheese grater), minced garlic, soy sauce, sesame oil, sliced green onion an shredded carrot. Mix them all together well with your hands. Add the shredded and cooked cabbage and mix again until it is evenly incorporated (you almost have to use your hands here). Refrigerate the mixture for at least one hour to let the flavors blend. (The cabbage will release gasses as it refrigerates and smell pretty stinky when you come back to it but don\u2019t be afraid. It\u2019s still good and the smell will go away when you cook the pot stickers.)", "name": "While the cabbage is sauteing (stir every minute or so), combine the raw ground pork, peeled and grated ginger (use a small cheese grater), minced garlic, soy sauce, sesame oil, sliced green onion an shredded carrot. Mix them all together well with your hands. Add the shredded and cooked cabbage and mix again until it is evenly incorporated (you almost have to use your hands here). Refrigerate the mixture for at least one hour to let the flavors blend. (The cabbage will release gasses as it refrigerates and smell pretty stinky when you come back to it but don\u2019t be afraid. It\u2019s still good and the smell will go away when you cook the pot stickers.)", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/pork-ginger-pot-stickers/#wprm-recipe-33891-step-0-2"}, {"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "FOR THE POT STICKERS:", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare your workspace by getting a small dish of water (used to glue the edges together), something to fold the pot stickers on (I used a cutting board) and something to keep them on once folded (another cutting board or large plate). I used square wrappers so the wrapping technique below is based on that. There are many methods to folding pot stickers/won tons so if you have a different shape, simply do a google search for \u201cfolding won tons\u201d or \u201cfolding pot stickers\u201d to see more methods.", "name": "Prepare your workspace by getting a small dish of water (used to glue the edges together), something to fold the pot stickers on (I used a cutting board) and something to keep them on once folded (another cutting board or large plate). I used square wrappers so the wrapping technique below is based on that. There are many methods to folding pot stickers/won tons so if you have a different shape, simply do a google search for \u201cfolding won tons\u201d or \u201cfolding pot stickers\u201d to see more methods.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/pork-ginger-pot-stickers/#wprm-recipe-33891-step-1-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "To make things easier, fill and fold the wontons in groups. I filled and folded three then moved on to the next group. Take three won ton wrappers and lay them on your surface. Using your finger, wet all the way around the edge of the wrapper. Place about 1 tsp of pork filling in the center of each square. Fold the square over diagonally from one corner to the opposite corner. Press down all along the seam to make the wet edges stick. Squeeze out all of the air in the process.", "name": "To make things easier, fill and fold the wontons in groups. I filled and folded three then moved on to the next group. Take three won ton wrappers and lay them on your surface. Using your finger, wet all the way around the edge of the wrapper. Place about 1 tsp of pork filling in the center of each square. Fold the square over diagonally from one corner to the opposite corner. Press down all along the seam to make the wet edges stick. Squeeze out all of the air in the process.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/pork-ginger-pot-stickers/#wprm-recipe-33891-step-1-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Take the two points of the triangle that are furthest from each other and wrap them around front and pinch together (use a bit more water to glue it together). The pot sticker is now folded! Fold the rest in the same manner. Once all of the pot stickers are folded, you can either cook all of them or freeze some on a cookie sheet. Once they are completely frozen solid, transfer them to an air tight freezer bag for storage. You can take them out and cook them as usual at a later date!", "name": "Take the two points of the triangle that are furthest from each other and wrap them around front and pinch together (use a bit more water to glue it together). The pot sticker is now folded! Fold the rest in the same manner. Once all of the pot stickers are folded, you can either cook all of them or freeze some on a cookie sheet. Once they are completely frozen solid, transfer them to an air tight freezer bag for storage. You can take them out and cook them as usual at a later date!", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/pork-ginger-pot-stickers/#wprm-recipe-33891-step-1-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large pot, bring 6 cups of water and 3 bouillon cubes to a boil. Once it reaches a hard boil, drop in about half of the pot stickers. Boil them until they begin to float (about 7 minutes) then transfer to a cooling rack to drain. Place a baking sheet under the cooling rack to catch any water that drips off.", "name": "In a large pot, bring 6 cups of water and 3 bouillon cubes to a boil. Once it reaches a hard boil, drop in about half of the pot stickers. Boil them until they begin to float (about 7 minutes) then transfer to a cooling rack to drain. Place a baking sheet under the cooling rack to catch any water that drips off.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/pork-ginger-pot-stickers/#wprm-recipe-33891-step-1-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once the pot stickers are done boiling and have drained for a minute or two they are ready to fry. Heat a large non-stick skillet over medium/high heat. Spray it generously with non-stick spray. Using a non-stick pan with non-stick spray is the easiest way to make the pot stickers crispy without having them stick, tear and use a ton of oil. Pan fry the pot stickers on each side until golden brown and crispy (2-3 min on each side).", "name": "Once the pot stickers are done boiling and have drained for a minute or two they are ready to fry. Heat a large non-stick skillet over medium/high heat. Spray it generously with non-stick spray. Using a non-stick pan with non-stick spray is the easiest way to make the pot stickers crispy without having them stick, tear and use a ton of oil. Pan fry the pot stickers on each side until golden brown and crispy (2-3 min on each side).", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/pork-ginger-pot-stickers/#wprm-recipe-33891-step-1-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Serve immediately with your favorite asian sauce (soy, oyster, teriyaki, sweet chili\u2026 anything goes!).", "name": "Serve immediately with your favorite asian sauce (soy, oyster, teriyaki, sweet chili\u2026 anything goes!).", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/pork-ginger-pot-stickers/#wprm-recipe-33891-step-1-5"}]}], "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "ratingValue": "4.75", "ratingCount": "4", "reviewCount": "4"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I had a hard time figuring out the size of my cabbage. I made a dipping sauce of chili paste, soy sauce, and honey.\u00a0\r\n\r\nAlso, cover your wrappers with a wet paper towel to keep them from drying out. The rolling took me a looong time (perfect quarantine recipe).\u00a0", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Meredith"}, "datePublished": "2020-04-04"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I made this today with a few changes.  These are really good, at least as good as what I've had at restaurants or from Trader Joe's.  My husband loved them too.  I used ground turkey, napa cabbage and added a teaspoon or two of chili garlic sauce.    The folding method was really easy and quick.  Yours was the only recipe I saw that boiled and then fried so I wasn't sure I would like it, but it was pretty easy and they had a great texture.  I served them with Trader Joe's Gyoza dipping sauce (which is so good I could drink it) and that was perfect.  This recipe has a lot of steps and hands-on time, but I got 45 from the recipe and am so excited to have a big tray of them in the freezer for future deliciousness.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Kimberly"}, "datePublished": "2017-07-21"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Hey there, I love your website, being a college kid and eating well is rare but thanks to you I can! Which ones should I use with this recipe?", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Jackie"}, "datePublished": "2015-03-14"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "reviewBody": "I made these a few weeks ago, but my wonton folding was TERRIBLE. Of the dozen I made, only about 5 made it to the final stage to eat. I tried many different folding methods, but the one you showed here was the best! \r\n\r\nI finally made acceptable final products today. From this I have two tips:\r\n1) Don't try to make these when you're hungry for them! Folding takes patience.\r\n2) A change in cooking method: Lightly oil a pan, add in the pot stickers, then immediately pouring boiling water to the pan, covering the pot stickers half-way. Then simmer until all the water is gone and add sesame oil to fry for 1 minute.\r\n\r\nI froze the stuffing mixture after my first failure. I was surprised at how the cabbage stayed crispy despite freezing and thawing! \r\n\r\nThese pot stickers have been shared with many friends who say they taste just like (or better than) the ones we get as appetizers in restaurants!\r\n\r\nAs always: Thanks so much for an amazing recipe!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Malorie"}, "datePublished": "2014-08-13"}], "recipeCategory": Perfect for a cozy weekend breakfast.Step-by-step photos can be seen below the recipe card.", "datePublished": "2025-06-02T08:30:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Homemade-Pancakes-fork-side.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Homemade-Pancakes-fork-side-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Homemade-Pancakes-fork-side-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Homemade-Pancakes-fork-side-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Easy Homemade Pancakes", "description": "This easy homemade pancake recipe makes the most delicious and fluffy stack of pancakes around! Perfect for a cozy weekend breakfast. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/homemade-pancakes/\n\nIngredients\n1 cup all-purpose flour ($0.07)\n1.5 tsp baking powder ($0.03)\n1/2 tsp salt ($0.03)\n\u00be cup +2 Tbsp warm milk* ($0.02)\n2 Tbsp melted butter ($0.20)\n1 large egg ($0.21)\n2 Tbsp sugar ($0.02)\n1/2 tsp vanilla extract ($0.14)\n4 tsp cooking oil ($0.05)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Whisk together the flour, baking powder, and salt in a bowl.\n2. In a separate bowl, whisk together the milk, egg, melted butter, sugar, and vanilla extract.\n3. Pour the bowl of wet ingredients into the bowl of dry ingredients and stir until combined. The mixture should be thick, but still pourable. It\u2019s okay if the mixture is a bit lumpy. Let the batter rest for 15 minutes.\n4. Heat a large skillet or griddle over medium. Once hot add enough cooking oil to coat the surface (I use about \u00bd tsp per pancake). Add the pancake batter to the hot griddle, \u00bc cup at a time. Use the back of the measuring cup to spread the batter into a 4.5-inch diameter circle.\n5. Cook the pancakes until bubbles form over the surface and begin to pop, the edges of the pancakes look dry, and the bottom is golden brown (about 60 seconds). Flip the pancakes and cook on the second side until golden brown (about 30 seconds).\n6. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more oil to the skillet between batches or as needed, until all of the pancakes have been cooked. Keep the pancakes warm on a plate under a towel or in a warm oven until all of the pancakes have been cooked. Serve warm with your favorite toppings!\n\nNotes\n*\u00be cup of milk makes a super thick batter, but slightly dry pancake. One cup of milk makes a thinner batter and pancakes that are not quite as thick and fluffy. \u00be cup plus 2 Tbsp milk made perfectly thick and fluffy pancakes. You can adjust the milk to make the batter the consistency that you prefer. Using slightly warm milk helps the butter stay melted, which allows it to incorporate evenly into the batter.\n\nSee how we calculate costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:08 Combine dry ingredients in a bowl\n0:13 Whisk together wet ingredients\n0:21 Combine wet and dry ingredients\n0:28 Heat skillet\n0:31 Add the pancake batter \n0:37 Flip pancake \n0:41 Keep cooked pancakes warm\n0:49 Serve and ENJOY\n\nhttps://www.budgetbytes.com/homemade-pancakes/", "uploadDate": "2022-05-08T13:00:10+00:00", "duration": "PT1M4S", "thumbnailUrl": They tasted good but they\u2019re like biscuits", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Tommy"}, "datePublished": "2025-07-02"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Don't like pancakes myself, but since the entire family adores them, I've learned a few tricks over the 70 years I've been making them (I was 11 when I started doing much of the family cooking, due to my mother's illness but under her careful instructions). Beth has included the key ones in this recipe. First, and vital, the 15 minute wait!!! The purpose is two-fold--it  lets the flour get absorbed into the liquid, and starts the leavening to work. This works for both scratch made pancakes and those from mixes. Also important is to purchase baking powder in small amounts and replace often, certainly within a year so it's fresh and lively. If the baking power is a bit aged, try adding 50% more than a recipe calls for--it may help, but no guarantees. \r\n\r\nHonestly, that 15 minute wait isn't a hardship. Start your batter and then do all of the other little breakfast chores. Set the table, start the coffee, get your sides ready: that bowl of fruit or glasses of juice, heat your grill or skillet, whip some cream to go along with fresh fruit, put syrup on the table, etc. That 15 minute wait passes in less time than I ever imagine.\r\n\r\nI make 4\" pancakes and use a 12\" cast iron skillet which holds 3 at a time. I also use a 1/4 cup measure as Beth suggests. Larger pancakes are hard to turn. This recipe makes between 5-7--it's hard to make each of them perfect. Pancakes hold well in the fridge for a couple of days and revive in the toaster--up to a couple of months in the freezer. "https://www.budgetbytes.com/#/schema/person/image/", "url": "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ba1bd0462fb679d2843531eee7ec6006d9d8bd5e121185288552dd38fcf68b6a?s=96&d=mm&r=g", "contentUrl":
